results.title: Footloose
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Lewis Rachmil, Craig Zadan and Herbert Ross
results.brief_description: Ren MacCormack (Kevin Bacon) moves to Bomont, a small Midwestern town with his mother (Frances Lee McCain). The town is autocratically run by the local minister, Reverend Shaw Moore (John Lithgow). A fatal car accident has caused the reverend to prohibit music, because of the corruptive influence it has over teenagers. His daughter Ariel (Lori Singer) is opposed to her father’s views and is drawn to Ren because of his life in another place where music isn’t banned, and for the possibility that he could take her away from Bomont. Ren pushes the boundaries of the Bomont community when he tries to convince the council to allow them to have a dance. Features a great soundtrack with songs from Kenny Loggins and Bonnie Tyler.

results.title: Footlight parade
results.creator_credit: Lloyd Bacon, Warner Bros Pictures and Robert Lord
results.brief_description: Set against the backdrop of Hollywood in the 1930’s, James Cagney stars as a Broadway musical comedy producer/director who finds himself without a job due to the arrival of talkies. He devises an inventive way of keeping the loan sharks at bay, by creating prologues that can precede the talkies themselves, riding on the coat tails of the very thing that put him out of business in the first place. The comedy and drama of the film is derived from the activities of the players who are part of Cagney’s troupe producing the prologues. There’s the gold digger (Claire Dodd), the disgruntled ex-wife (Renee Whitney), the secretary with secret artistic abilities (Ruby Keeler), the faithful Girl Friday (Joan Blondell) who stands by the man who doesn’t know that she loves him, the long suffering personal assistant (Hugh Herbert), and the young protegee (Dick Powell). Numbers created and staged by Busby Berkeley and include hits such as “Honeymoon hotel”, “Shanghai Lil” and “By a waterfall”. This was the third of Warner’s backstage musicals released in 1933, the other two being “42nd Street” and “The Gold diggers of 1933”.

results.title: Fools rush in
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Doug Draizin and Andy Tennant
results.brief_description: Alex Whitman is a high-flying New York yuppie sent by his company to open a nightclub in Las Vegas. It is a reluctant move for him, though once there, he meets the beautiful Mexican photographer, Isabel Fuentes. Though opposites in nearly every way, romantic sparks fly and the two have a passionate one night stand. Three months later, Isabel shows up pregnant with his child and every intention of keeping it. The two hastily marry in a Vegas chapel while an Elvis impersonator acts as the witness. A head-on collision of cultures ensues, prompting the contemplation of a break-up. A large family gathering, planned by Isabel, grows larger due to surprise family guests, thus creating a comedy of errors before the story draws to its predictable romantic close. Cast includes Matthew Perry, Salma Hayek, Jon Tenney, Carlos Gomez and Tomas Milian.

results.title: Foolish wives
results.creator_credit: Universal Productions and Erich Von Stroheim
results.brief_description: Posing as a Russian count, Stroheim preys on women; regardless of social class or status. Set in Monte Carlo, the subject matter was considered “repulsive and continental.” Stroheim, bewitching in his monacle is a satanic seducer intent on possessing the wife of an American diplomat from under his nose. The wife is more than obviously attracted to the Count’s fatal charm. “Foolish wives” was an expensive production in its day, and the excellence of the sets and costumes, along with Stroheim’s masterly direction make it a cinema classic.

results.title: Fool for love
results.creator_credit: Cannon Group, Menahem Golan, Yoram Globus and Robert Altman
results.brief_description: Robert Altman (The Player, McCabe and Mrs Miller, Nashville, Gosford Park) adapts Sam Shepard’s one room play with mixed results. Shepard plays Eddie, a handsome cowboy drifter who arrives in a depressing New Mexico roadside motel, lugging a trailer and horses. The aim of Eddie’s visit is to be re-united with the voluptuous May, a barmaid at this barren pit stop’s hotel. For her part May is being wooed by another man but is inextricably drawn to Eddie, despite the proven destructive nature of their union. Over the course of the evening she and Eddie argue violently and make up passionately as the heart-rending history of their relationship, replete with flashbacks, unfurls. Harry Dean Stanton plays a barfly whose identity holds a key role to these lovers’ sorrow. “Fool for love” garnered mostly negative reviews and found a very limited audience, regardless of praise for Basinger’s bravura performance. Most decried the device of opening up the play, outside of its claustrophobic one room structure, in favour of a wider locale, which may have robbed it of the intimate tensions generated by the ill-matched pair battling it out in a confined space. But despite this the incendiary relationship between the principal characters is astutely portrayed, achieving a suitably tragic tone within a desolate setting.

results.title: Fontane Effi Briest = Effi Briest
results.creator_credit: Tango Film, Filverlag der Authoren and Rainer Werner Fassbinder
results.brief_description: Possibly Fassbinder’s most exquisite film, this is the story of a seventeen year old girl stifled in a loveless marriage, too naive to understand that her liaison with one of her husband’s friends risks bringing disaster on both of them. Using carefully stylised visuals and performances, Fassbinder produces not a conventional literary adaptation but a searching study of the ways that people can unwittingly conspire in their own downfall. From the novel by Theodor Fontane. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Follow that bird
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Tony Garnett and Ken Kwapis
results.brief_description: Big Bird goes to stay with the Dodo family in Illinois, but soon realizes he really belongs with the variety of inhabitants on Sesame Street. Adapted from the very popular children’s television series, “Sesame Street”, this wonderful muppet film features Oscar, Bert, Ernie, Cookie Monster and many of the other loved characters from the television show. Delightful entertainment for all the family. Stars Chevy Chase, Sandra Bernhard, Waylon Jennings, Dave Thomas and John Candy in cameo roles and the voices of Carroll Spinney, Jim Henson, Frank Oz, Paul Bartel and others.

results.title: Fly away home
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, John Veitch, Carol Baum and Carroll Ballard
results.brief_description: After the shocking loss of her mother in a car crash, 14 year old Amy (Anna Paquin), reluctantly moves from New Zealand to Canada to live with her estranged father (Jeff Daniels). Amy’s feelings of isolation are heightened by her father’s aloofness and preoccupation with his own inventions. Amy’s grief is allayed when she befriends a batch of goose eggs whose survival is threatened by the destruction of their natural habitat by developers. Amy becomes surrogate mother to the eggs, nursing them through to hatching. A problem develops when their surrogate mother must teach them how to fly south for the winter as part of their natural migration. The only solution seems to be for Amy to fly an ultralight plane, masquerading as the mother goose, to teach her ‘children’ to fly. Cast includes Anna Paquin, Jeff Daniels and Dana Delaney. Inspired by the true story of Bill Lishman who successfully found and raised a clutch of Canadian geese.

results.title: Flubber
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Pictures, Great Oaks, John Hughes, Ricardo Mestres and Les Mayfield
results.brief_description: In this colourful remake of ‘The Absent Minded Professor’ (1961), Robin Williams plays Professor Philip Brainard, a brilliant off the wall inventor with an unfortunate short term memory. Flubber, his latest creation is a green rubber-like substance, which has the capacity to give objects flight. Potentially a gold mine for the professor and his college (which is near bankruptcy), the invention receives the unwelcome attention of Brainard’s spiteful nemesis Wilson Croft (Christopher McDonald), who has his own plans for the gravity-defying matter. The romantic subplot which involves a bizarre love triangle between Brainard, his long suffering fiance Sara (Marcia Gay Harden), and a female robot with a jealous streak called Weebo (Jodi Benson), give the film some surprisingly poignant moments, mainly due to Harden’s tender performance. Music by Danny Elfman and screenplay by John Hughes and Bill Walsh.

results.title: Flirt
results.creator_credit: True Fiction Pictures, Pandora Films, Nippon Film Development & Finance, Ted Hope and Hal Hartley
results.brief_description: If you’re interested in the art of storytelling, then you’ll enjoy “Flirt”. Hal Hartley takes the same narrative and retells it three times, changing the cultural and gender contexts of each story. Set in America, Berlin, and Tokyo, the same twisted love story unfolds with the same quirky twists and dramatic conclusion. Hartley flirts with the audience as he playfully includes many self-conscious allusions to his role as the ‘storyteller’, even including himself as a player in the final version of the narrative. While “Flirt” may not have the same dramatic intensity of some of Hartley’s other films, it becomes compelling through the differences and similarities revealed with each new unfolding of the narrative.
